data.benefits: The scheme reimburses 25% of the prescribed stipend, up to a maximum of Rs 0.015 lakhs per month per apprentice, to employers engaging apprentices.
data.eligibility: The minimum age for an apprentice is 14 years, and for apprenticeships in hazardous industries, the minimum age is 18 years, as per Section 3(a) of the Apprentices Act, 1961.
data.conditions: Establishment contracts must be uploaded for approval on the portal, courses must be NSQF-aligned, and assessments at the end of the program must be jointly conducted by the establishment and the NCVT or relevant Sector Skill Council.
data.beneficiaries: As per Section 3(a) of the Apprentices Act, 1961, the minimum age for an apprentice is 14 years. However, for apprenticeships in hazardous industries or jobs that may be deemed dangerous, the minimum age is set at 18 years to ensure the safety and well-being of the apprentices. This regulation aims to protect minors from engaging in work environments that could pose risks to their health and safety.
data.prerequisites:
Such contracts must be uploaded by establishment for approval by the concerned apprenticeship advisor, which shall be facilitated on the portal
the Courses they operate under the apprenticeship program must be NSQF aligned.
the assessments at the end of all such programs must be done jointly between the establishment and the NCVT (for Designated Trades) / the concerned Sector Skill council (in case of Optional trade).
data.context: Promote apprenticeship training in the country, by providing partial stipend support to the apprentices engaged under the Apprentice Act, 1961, undertaking capacity building of the apprenticeship ecosystem, and providing advocacy assistance to the stakeholders.
data.objective:
Promote apprenticeship training in India.
Provide financial support to establishments, particularly MSMEs, to engage apprentices by reimbursing 25% of the prescribed stipend, up to Rs. 1,500 per month per apprentice.
Support MSMEs without in-house basic training facilities by reimbursing up to Rs. 7,500 per apprentice for Basic Training costs (for up to 500 hours).
data.description: Partial stipend support by GoI under NAPS-2 will be limited to 25% of stipend paid, up to a maximum of Rs.1,500 per month, per apprentice during the training period.
data.how_to_apply: The applicants can apply through: https://www.apprenticeshipindia.gov.in/
data.funding_mechanism: The stipend support by GoI will be paid through Direct Benefit Transfer (DBT) to the bank account of apprentices.
data.checklist_info_a:
For Employers (Establishments)
Establishment Registration Proof: Legal documents like GST Registration or Shop & Establishment License.
Establishment Profile: Details about the industry sector, training capacity, and business nature.
Apprenticeship Agreement: Signed agreement outlining terms and conditions with apprentices.
Bank Account Details: For stipend reimbursement (if applicable).
Basic Training Facility Proof (if applicable): In-house or outsourced training facility or agreement with Basic Training Provider (BTP).
Training Plan: Detailed training schedule, modules, mentors, and methods.
For Apprentices (Trainees)
Aadhar Card: For identity verification.
Educational Certificates: ITI, degree, or other relevant qualifications.
Photographs: Recent passport-sized photo.
Date of Birth Proof: Birth certificate or valid document showing age.
Aadhar Linked Bank Details: Bank account linked with Aadhar for stipend DBT.
For Stipend Reimbursement (if applicable)
Apprenticeship Registration Confirmation: Proof of registration on the NATS portal.
Attendance Records: Documented attendance and training participation.
Reimbursement Claim Form: Completed form along with necessary supporting documents for stipend claim.
data.checklist_info_d:
